title: Made Hands
description: Learn when to hold winning hands and when to break them for better draws.

sections.title: What is a Made Hand?
sections.content:
A made hand is any 5-card combination that already pays out. In Jacks or Better, this includes:

• Jacks or Better (pair of J, Q, K, or A)
• Two Pair
• Three of a Kind
• Straight
• Flush
• Full House
• Four of a Kind
• Straight Flush
• Royal Flush

When you're dealt a made hand, you need to decide: should you keep it, or break it for a better draw?

sections.title: The Golden Rule
sections.content:
Never break a made hand unless you have a higher expected value (EV) draw.

In most cases, you should hold your made hand. But there are specific exceptions where breaking a hand is mathematically correct.

sections.title: Keep the Flush
sections.content: You have a flush with a 4-card royal draw. Should you break it?

exampleHand.explanation: Keep all 5 cards. A flush pays 6 coins, and the 4-to-royal draw only has a 1-in-47 chance of hitting. The EV of keeping the flush is higher.

sections.title: Break the Flush for a Royal
sections.content: What about this flush with a 4-card royal?

exampleHand.explanation: Break the flush! Hold the 4-to-royal (T-J-Q-K). Unlike the previous example, you have 4 consecutive high cards. The royal pays 800 coins (4000 with max bet), making the draw worthwhile.

sections.title: Key Exception
sections.content: Always break a flush or straight to draw to a royal if you have 4 to the royal. The royal's massive payout (800:1) justifies the risk.

sections.title: Two Pair - Never Break It
sections.content: You have two pair. Should you ever break it?

exampleHand.explanation: Keep both pairs. Two pair pays 2 coins and has a 1-in-12 chance of improving to a full house. Never break two pair.

sections.title: Three of a Kind
sections.content: What about three of a kind with a 4-flush draw?

exampleHand.explanation: Keep the three 7s. Three of a kind pays 3 coins and can improve to a full house (1-in-16) or four of a kind (1-in-47). The 4-flush draw isn't worth breaking trips.

sections.title: Summary: When to Hold Made Hands
sections.content:
• Always hold: Two Pair, Three of a Kind, Full House, Four of a Kind
• Usually hold: Flush, Straight
• Break for: 4-to-Royal (from flush or straight)
• Never break: Straight Flush or Royal Flush
